title: Greek Walnut Cake 'Karidopita'

ingredients.content: 2 ½ oz unsalted butter, plus extra to grease
6 oz all-purpose flour, plus extra to dust
2 oz stale bread, broken into pieces
½ organic lemon, thin peel only, no pith

preparations.content: Preheat oven to 350°F. Grease and flour a springform pan (10 in.) and set aside.
Place bread into mixing bowl and grate <b>15 sec/speed 7<b>.
Add walnuts and chop <b>4 sec/speed 7<b>. Transfer to a large bowl and set aside.
Place flour and cloves into mixing bowl and grind <b>20 sec/speed 10<b>. Transfer into bowl with bread-walnut mixture.
Place butter, eggs and sugar into mixing bowl and whip <b>2 min/speed 4<b>.

Add reserved bread-walnut-flour mixture, cinnamon, baking powder, brandy and milk and mix <b>25 sec/speed 4<b>. Transfer mixture to prepared springform pan and bake for 50-60 minutes (350°F). Allow cake to cool in pan. Meanwhile, clean mixing bowl
Place 3 oz sugar and lemon peel into mixing bowl and zest <b>30 sec/speed 10<b>.
Add remaining 15 oz sugar and water. Split vanilla pod lengthwise, scrape out seeds and add seeds and vanilla pod into mixing bowl and cook <b>9 min/212°F/speed 1<b>.
Remove vanilla pod. Pour syrup over cooled walnut cake and wait until all the syrup is absorbed. Slice cake and serve.

hintsAndTricks: Greek walnut cake “Karidopita”: one of the most popular cakes in Greece made with walnuts and bread, giving a soft but crunchy texture in every bite. Its texture, thanks to soaking in sugar syrup, is surprisingly sponge-like.
Brandy can be replaced with prune juice, apple cider or simply water.
To optimize the absorption of syrup use a wooden skewer to evenly poke holes in the cake, allowing syrup to be more uniformly absorbed. Top cake with finely chopped walnuts to cover skewer holes.
